facts.text: Gopal deceased was married to the sister of the appellant.
The appellant and his father Badri were living in a railway quarter at Gorakhpur.
Gopal's wife continued to live with her father Badri as she was unwilling to go with Gopal. Her father Badri and her brother Vishwanath appellant sided with her and refused to let her go with Gopal.
Gopal had been living for some time with his father-in-law but shifted to the house of Banarsi about 15 days before the occurrence on June 11, 1953.
Gopal suspected that his wife had been carrying on with one Moti who used to visit Badri's quarter.
On June 11, 1953, there was some quarrel between the appellant and Gopal about the girl but nothing untoward happened then.
Gopal asked Banarsi's sons to help him bring back his wife. Banarsi arrived and all four went to Badri's quarter.
Banarsi and his two sons stood outside while Gopal went in. Badri came out and was asked by Banarsi to let the girl go with her husband but Badri was not agreeable.
Gopal came out dragging his reluctant wife. The girl caught hold of the door and a tug-of-war followed.
The appellant shouted to his father that Gopal was adamant. Badri replied that if Gopal was adamant he should be beaten tomaro.
The appellant took out a knife from his pocket and stabbed Gopal once. The knife penetrated into the heart and Gopal fell down senseless.
Gopal was taken to the hospital by Badri, the appellant, Banarsi and his sons but Gopal died by the time they reached.
Sessions Judge acquitted Badri of abetment and acquitted appellant holding right of private defence extended to causing death but more harm than necessary was not caused.
High Court upheld acquittal of Badri but set aside acquittal of appellant, convicted under s.304 Part II, sentenced to 3 years RI, relying on Emperor v. Ram Saiya.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant had exceeded the right of private defence of person.
Whether the word 'abducting' in the fifth clause of s.100 IPC refers only to abduction that is an offence under the IPC or to abduction as defined in s.362 IPC.
Whether the appellant inflicted more harm than necessary under s.99 IPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: The decision in Ram Saiya's case is incorrect.

respondent_arguments.text: The case is not covered by the fifth clause of s.100 IPC as abduction must be an offence, right of private defence does not extend to voluntary causing of death.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Emperor v. Ram Saiya; s.100 IPC

court_reasoning.text: On a plain reading of the fifth clause of s.100, 'abducting' means abduction as defined in s.362, not necessarily an offence. Assault with intention to abduct by force triggers extended right to cause death.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The view in Ram Saiya's case is incorrect.

court_reasoning.text: Right of private defence arises against offence of assault (s.352), and if assault is with intention of abducting by force, s.100 fifth clause applies without needing further criminal intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to pause and consider abductor's further intention.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant gave only one blow with knife which happened to be fatal, but considering circumstances, not more harm than necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: These things cannot be weighed in too fine scales.

holdings.text: Fifth clause of s.100 IPC applies to assault with intention of abducting as defined in s.362, extends right to cause death.
Appellant did not exceed right of private defence; within s.99 restrictions.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held that 'abducting' in s.100 fifth clause requires abduction to be an offence; court disagrees.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court's conviction under s.304 Part II set aside; appellant acquitted as he acted in right of private defence without exceeding it.

key_quotes.text: On a plain reading, however, of that clause there does not seem to be any reason for holding that the word abducting used there means anything more than what is defined as abduction in s. 362.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation rejecting Ram Saiya view.

key_quotes.text: It would...be not right to expect from a person who is being abducted by force to pause and consider whether the abductor has further intention as provided in one of the sections of the Penal Code...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies immediate defence without probing intent.
